name: Vita Genetic Programming Framework
description:
Vita is a scalable, high performance genetic programming / algorithms framework.

It's suitable for classification, symbolic regression, content base image retrieval, data mining and agent control.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/morinim/vita/wiki/development_cycle
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/morinim/vita/wiki/
repo_public_justification: https://github.com/morinim/vita
repo_track_justification: https://github.com/morinim/vita Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them and when they were made. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub (which uses git). Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification:
We adopt continuous integration (CI). Each CI build produces a version of the software, referred to as a CI artifact (or interim version). Most CI artifacts **are not published**. For example, in the run-up to version 3.0.0, a developer may push changes several times. Every push generates its own CI artifact. The developer publishes only the last one as 3.0.0.

**Published releases are tagged** (`major.minor.patch` format). The latest published release can be found with the `git describe --abbrev=0 --tags master` command.
warnings_strict_justification: Kernel compiles without warning with with `--std=c++14 -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic`
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Standard C/C++ `assert` macro (from `cassert` standard library) and `ensures` / `expects` *ad hoc* assertions.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
documentation_current_justification: https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/NEWS.md includes information about differences or changes between versions of the software.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Utilities have a (at least) a text-based user interface and/or a command line interface with built-in usage help.
maintenance_or_update_justification: The NEWS file (https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/NEWS.md) documents these aspects.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: There have been no vulnerabilities reported in the last 12 months.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: See the **security issues** section in CONTRIBUTING.md (https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#contributing). At the moment *full disclosure* seems a valid choice for **this project**.
coding_standards_enforced_justification:
There are:
- a template for git commit messages (https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/misc/gitmessage);
- an Emacs style file (https://github.com/morinim/vita/blob/master/misc/vita-style.el).

There isn't a FLOSS tool that completely covers the coding style requirements (the included cpplint.py just covers some aspects).
build_standard_variables_justification: CMake honors `CXX`, `CC`, `CXXFLAGS` and `CFLAGS` environment variables, using them to initialize the corresponding `CMAKE` variables.
copyright_per_file_justification:
Doxygen format in use:

```
/// \copyright Copyright (C) 2012-2018 EOS di Manlio Morini.
```

repo_interim_justification: The git repository has all interim versions of the software
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Ocarina version identifier uses the calver scheme
version_semver_justification: calver scheme is the preferred way
version_tags_justification: We use GitHub tag for each release
release_notes_justification: Release notes are build as part of GitHub release mechanism. See https://github.com/OpenAADL/ocarina/releases
report_responses_justification: Acknowledgement is usually performed at this pace.
enhancement_responses_justification: Acknowledgement is usually performed at this pace.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerability report received. This is unlikely to happen.
build_justification: Provided as part of the ocarina-build project: https://github.com/openaadl/ocarina-build
build_common_tools_justification: We rely on GCC/GNAT, Autotools and Python only for building
build_floss_tools_justification: Automated build procedure relies only on FLOSS tools
test_invocation_justification: Testsuite can be run directly from the ocarina-build script: https://github.com/openaadl/ocarina-build
test_most_justification: The test suite is run automatically through travis-ci on all branches. Codecov.io reports on code coverage and demonstrates most functionalities
test_policy_justification: All non trivial changes are associated to an issue, and a test is filed.
warnings_justification:
Compiler flags used are in https://github.com/OpenAADL/ocarina/blob/master/projects/ocarina.gpr.in 

We check for most warnings, treated as errors (-gnatwae). GNAT front-end is powerful enough to be considered a linter.
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are considered as errors. They are all addressed
warnings_strict_justification: Warnings are considered as errors, it is the strictest level.
know_secure_design_justification: Lead developper has knowledge in software, programming languages and OS at large. His research activities in on safety-critical software
know_common_errors_justification: Lead developper has knowledge in software, programming languages and OS at large. His research activities in on safety-critical software
delivery_mitm_justification: Releases are available through GitHub releases, that uses https
delivery_unsigned_justification: The only hash used are git one, which are not delivered through HTTP
static_analysis_justification: No FLOSS tool exist for this language. CodePeer by AdaCore would be an option, but it is not yet available through their libre.adacore.com website
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: See above: no FLOSS static tool available
static_analysis_fixed_justification: See above: no FLOSS static tool available
static_analysis_often_justification: See above: no FLOSS static tool available
dynamic_analysis_justification: We use compilation in debug mode for testing with all Ada runtime checks activated, combined with run-time assertions and validity check. Furthermore, Ocarina uses only safe mechanism (no OO, limited memory allocation, etc). This is stricter than most dynamic checking tools for other languages.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Ocarina is written mostly in Ada, which is memory safe.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Ocarina has runtime assertions part of the Ada default checks, in addition to various assert added by the developing teams to assess the validity of internal data.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: So far, no vulnerability have been found
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We rely on travis-ci for continuous integration
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No credentials have been stored so far in the repository.
english_justification:
GitHub issues use english, documentation also in english, see
http://ocarina.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification:
Tool is installed using auto tools, and thus provides a "make install" target if compiled from source, uninstall is possible if build directory has been kept.

Installation from archive is reduced to copying a directory, uninstallation by deleting this directory.
build_reproducible_justification: Reproducible build is provided through docker files for debian, CentOS and Fedora ( https://github.com/OpenAADL/ocarina-docker )
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: Project is a code generator, it does not need cryptographic algorithms
crypto_credential_agility_justification: No need fur an authentication mechanism

floss_license_osi_justification: The LGPL-2.1 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). The LGPL-2.1-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The short description of all this is in README.md
documentation_interface_justification: Doxygen/Javadoc-styled comments are used throughout the API; there's also a requirement in CONTRIBUTING.md that new calls exposed in the API be accompanied by a doc comment.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: CI builds use git SHA identifiers; number releases are identified by numbers. Tags use unique progressive version numbers.
version_semver_justification: Although the API is unstable yet, we try to use sub-semantic versioning (that basically means that every version increases the minor number, leaving 0 in the major number until we reach stability).
release_notes_vulns_justification: Release notes at https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient/releases will be used for that - no CVE's or similar public records yet.
report_archive_justification: The archive of issues along with discussions is kept at https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerability reports in the last 6 months, but I'm around on daily basis anyway.
build_floss_tools_justification: CMake together with an entirely free build toolchain (e.g. gcc, clang on top of GNU/Linux) can be used for building.
test_justification: The library is automatically tested by compiling and running the end-to-end functional test provided within the source tree.
test_invocation_justification: There's a limited set of unit tests that can be executed using ctest, the official test driver for CMake. The end-to-end test application should be explicitly run; there's no integration of that into CMake yet.
warnings_justification: Several warning flags are used, including -Wall, -pedantic and others.
warnings_fixed_justification: GCC builds are kept free from warnings; Clang warnings are taken care of as well.
warnings_strict_justification: A set of warnings together with clang-tidy checks during development are deemed the best reasonable set for the project. See details in https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt
know_secure_design_justification: The main developer has gone through the relevant texts and practices the mentioned principles to the best of his understanding.
crypto_published_justification: The library doesn't immediately use any cryptography, instead relying on facilities provided by the underlying libraries (Qt).
crypto_floss_justification: There's no cryptography-dependent functionality within the software; external dependencies on cryptography include libolm (FLOSS) and OpenSSL (indirectly via Qt).
crypto_keylength_justification: The project doesn't handle cryptographical keys.
crypto_working_justification: The project doesn't handle cryptographical algorithms
crypto_pfs_justification: As of now, encryption is not used in the library. Once encryption is introduced, PFS will be engaged.
crypto_random_justification: The library doesn't generate cryptographical values.
delivery_mitm_justification: HTTPS and SSH can be used to download software sources (GitHub).
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: clang-tidy has rules aimed at secure programming; and CodeQL has been added recently.
static_analysis_often_justification: clang-tidy is invoked from inside the IDE so the checks occur as-I-code.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Valgrind is used in CI builds.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is used in CI builds.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Runtime assertions are used extensively throughout the code, and are added on a routine basis.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No vulnerabilities detected so far even close to that level.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The project doesn't handle cryptographical algorithms
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests; there's also a public Matrix room (matrix:r/quotient:matrix.org) for more interactive discussions - Matrix supports permalinks and discussions in this room are retained indefinitely.
english_justification: The working language of the project is English.
hardening_justification: No hardening mechanisms are in place so far.
crypto_used_network_justification: A user has to have OpenSSL for the code to run; the default used protocol is HTTPS, with HTTP still available if the user explicitly changes the connection line.
crypto_tls12_justification: The supported security protocols are up to the OpenSSL version supplied by the user.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: The supported security features are up to the OpenSSL version supplied by the user.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Certificate check failures are exposed in the API; clients should use this API to confirm the failures with the user. By default (without using this API), check failures lead to stopping communication.
hardened_site_justification: https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient
installation_common_justification: Standard CMake conventions (--target install, in particular) are used.
roles_responsibilities_justification: The list of team members is available at https://github.com/orgs/quotient-im/people, with roles indicated.
access_continuity_justification: Technically the project doesn't belong to a single person, a GitHub organisation owns it: https://github.com/quotient-im, and there's more than one admin in the organisation.
bus_factor_justification: Although the vast majority of contributions still arrive from a single person, the team behind NeoChat (https://invent.kde.org/network/neochat) accumulated extensive knowledge of the library and is able to take over the project if the lead developer is no more around.
documentation_architecture_justification: There's a work-in-progress document at the project's wiki: https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient/wiki/libQuotient-overview
documentation_quick_start_justification: An example application can be used as a starting point to use the library: https://github.com/QMatrixClient/libqmatrixclient/blob/master/examples/qmc-example.cpp
documentation_current_justification: Documentation is updated on a regular basis, along with the code.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The project doesn't produce software with user interface.
internationalization_justification: While there's no UI, the library has some strings intended to be read by end users - this text is made localisable.
maintenance_or_update_justification: One older version of libQuotient is supported; help in migration to the new version's API is provided through the chat room with libQuotient developers.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: In practice, the project is developed with automatic formatting according to the supplied .clang-format file. A deliberate decision not to enforce this on PRs has been made, as clang-format falls short when formatting certain code structures.
build_non_recursive_justification: There are no cross-dependencies in libQuotient subfolders.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Standard conventions are used; packages for several distributions are maintained: https://repology.org/metapackage/libquotient/information
external_dependencies_justification: Both CMake and packages track dependencies, see https://github.com/quotient-im/libQuotient/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt and, e.g., https://packages.debian.org/unstable/source/libquotient
dependency_monitoring_justification: There are no in-tree dependencies to be tracked; and the best effort is put into staying on as newest version of other dependencies as compatibility requirements allow.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Standard libraries and Qt are used as much as possible; the project relies on update mechanisms available for compilers, standard libraries, and Qt.
interfaces_current_justification: Using deprecated/obsolete API is not practised and/or encouraged.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: GitHub Actions pipeline executes an example application as a means of basic automatic testing, producing a report as a result.
regression_tests_added50_justification: As of 16-01-2020: only in 1 case out of 10 relevant issues a regression test has been added.
implement_secure_design_justification: The project practices "secure by design" principles.
input_validation_justification: Where possible, validity of URLs is checked using Qt means; otherwise, correct values are filtered for processing, rather than incorrect values thrown out.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The project doesn't handle cryptographical algorithms
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Access tokens are saved separately from other data.
copyright_per_file_justification: SPDX tags are used in the preamble of each source file.
license_per_file_justification: SPDX tags are used in the preamble of each source file.

name: kallithea
description: Kallithea, a member project of Software Freedom Conservancy, is a GPLv3'd, Free Software source code management system that supports two leading version control systems, Mercurial and Git, and has a web interface that is easy to use for users and admins. You can install Kallithea on your own server and host repositories for the version control system of your choice.

name: OpenCoarrays
description: A transport layer for coarray Fortran compilers. OpenCoarrays is a software library that provides an implementation of a Coarray Fortran runtime for compilers such as GFortran. The compiler compiles user code and generates calls to OpenCoarrays for Coarray Fortran language features. OpenCoarrays then handles the compiler generated code and interfaces with the underlying communication technology, such as MPI, GASNet or OpenMP.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/sourceryinstitute/OpenCoarrays/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/sourceryinstitute/OpenCoarrays/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification:
WIP test-suite and API documentation: https://sourceryinstitute.github.io/OpenCoarrays
The end user inputs are ultimately just according to the Fortran 2008 and 2015 language standard: http://j3-fortran.org/doc/year/17/17-007r1.pdf
The most relevant part is linked from the README: http://isotc.iso.org/livelink/livelink/nfetch/-8919044/8919782/8919787/16681398/ISO%2DIECJTC1%2DSC22%2DWG5_N2027_Draft_TS_18508_Additional_Paralle.pdf?nodeid=16769292&vernum=0
ABI info (somewhat dated, as co-development of OpenCoarrays and GFortran continues) is at https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gfortran/Coarray-Programming.html#Coarray-Programming
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We use "Github flow" workflow, where "master" is pseudo-stable. Any bug fix or new feature is developed on a separate branch and then merged in via a pull request with code review and discussion.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Versioning follows semantic versioning. Version numbers are tagged as x.y.z where x,y,z are integers.
version_tags_justification: GPG signed git tags are produced for each release.
release_notes_justification: Release notes are provided with on Github for each release, under https://github.com/sourceryinstitute/OpenCoarrays/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities.
test_most_justification: Testing code coverage is not yet as robust as we would like it, it's at 38% right now: https://codecov.io/gh/sourceryinstitute/OpenCoarrays
warnings_justification:
-Wall etc. for C and Fortran
shellcheck for bash scripts
delivery_mitm_justification: Release archives are generated from gpg signed git tags (and often commits too). The release archive is generated with `git archive` and gpg signature validity, commit SHA etc. is embedded in a .VERSION file in the archive. A SHA256 cryptographic hash is then formed from the release archive (verifiable with `shasum -c opencoarrays-x.y.z-SHA256.txt`) is generated, and then a detached GPG signature of the cryptographic hash file is generated. The three files are uploaded to github releases as release assets, and these are served over https.  https://github.com/sourceyinstitute/OpenCoarrays/releases/latest
delivery_unsigned_justification: SHA256 cryptographic hashes are formed for the release archive, and these are served over HTTPS. In addition, a detached GPG signature of the SHA256 hash is published.
static_analysis_justification: We should be applying static analysis to C code but don't yet... We DO apply static analysis to shell script code, YAML files, Docker files, and other assets. For Fortran, there are no freely available static analysis tools that support F2008/F2015.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: shellcheck flags potential issues and vulnerabilities. We need a C linter though.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: GH tokens are used for 3rd party services, which can be swiftly revoked if they end up leaking in a CI log, etc. In addition, SSH pub/private keys are used for Travis-CI rather than GH tokens, since git has a propensity to display the remote URL (with embedded token) when an error is encountered. Encrypted Travis-CI variables are used, git output is piped to /dev/null, and SSH public/private key authentication is used
crypto_used_network_justification: Only communication done by the software is through third party libraries like MPICH, OpenMPI, GASNet, etc.
crypto_tls12_justification: Does not use TLS or network comms directly
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Software in package managers, provides a powerful, user friendly `install.sh` script, and installable using standard CMake conventions.
